content.question: A GRAPHING CALCULATOR IS REQUIRED FOR THIS QUESTION.You are permitted to use your calculator to solve an equation, find the derivative of a function at a point, or calculate the value of a definite integral. However, you must clearly indicate the setup of your question, namely the equation, function, or integral you are using. If you use other built-in features or programs, you must show the mathematical steps necessary to produce your results. Your work must be expressed in standard mathematical notation rather than calculator syntax.Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>x</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> is a real number. <math alttext='The figure shows a 2 row table with 4 columns of data. The heading for row 1 is "h, in centimeters," and the heading for row 2 is "r of h, in centimeters." The data in the table are as follows. Column 1. h is 0; r of h is 2.5. Column 2. h is 6.2; r of h is 2.7. Column 3. h is 13; r of h is 4.3. Column 4. h is 20; r of h is 2.6. ' display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtable columnlines="solid solid solid solid none" equalrows="true" frame="solid" rowlines="solid solid none"><mtr><mtd><mi>h</mi><mspace width="0.4em"></mspace><mtext>(centimeters)</mtext></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>6.2</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>13</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>20</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mi>r</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>h</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded><mspace width="0.4em"></mspace><mtext>(centimeters)</mtext></mtd><mtd><mn>2.5</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>2.7</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>4.3</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>2.6</mn></mtd></mtr></mtable></math> Juice is sold in <math alttext="20" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>20</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>-centimeter-tall bottles with horizontal cross sections parallel to the base that are circles, as shown in the figure. The radius of the circular cross section at height <math alttext="h" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> above the base of the bottle is given by a differentiable function <math alttext="r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow></math>, where <math alttext="h" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="r of h" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>r</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>h</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> are measured in centimeters. Selected values of <math alttext="r of h" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>r</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>h</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> are given in the table shown. (a) Approximate <math alttext="r prime of 3.1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msup><mi>r</mi><mo>′</mo></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>3.1</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></math> using the average rate of change of <math alttext="r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> over the interval <math alttext="0 less than or equal to h, less than or equal to 6.2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>h</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>6.2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Show the computations that lead to your answer. Indicate units of measure.

frqParts.text: A GRAPHING CALCULATOR IS REQUIRED FOR THIS QUESTION.You are permitted to use your calculator to solve an equation, find the derivative of a function at a point, or calculate the value of a definite integral. However, you must clearly indicate the setup of your question, namely the equation, function, or integral you are using. If you use other built-in features or programs, you must show the mathematical steps necessary to produce your results. Your work must be expressed in standard mathematical notation rather than calculator syntax.Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>x</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> is a real number. <math alttext='The figure shows a 2 row table with 4 columns of data. The heading for row 1 is "h, in centimeters," and the heading for row 2 is "r of h, in centimeters." The data in the table are as follows. Column 1. h is 0; r of h is 2.5. Column 2. h is 6.2; r of h is 2.7. Column 3. h is 13; r of h is 4.3. Column 4. h is 20; r of h is 2.6. ' display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtable columnlines="solid solid solid solid none" equalrows="true" frame="solid" rowlines="solid solid none"><mtr><mtd><mi>h</mi><mspace width="0.4em"></mspace><mtext>(centimeters)</mtext></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>6.2</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>13</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>20</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mi>r</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>h</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded><mspace width="0.4em"></mspace><mtext>(centimeters)</mtext></mtd><mtd><mn>2.5</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>2.7</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>4.3</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>2.6</mn></mtd></mtr></mtable></math> Juice is sold in <math alttext="20" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>20</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>-centimeter-tall bottles with horizontal cross sections parallel to the base that are circles, as shown in the figure. The radius of the circular cross section at height <math alttext="h" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> above the base of the bottle is given by a differentiable function <math alttext="r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow></math>, where <math alttext="h" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="r of h" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>r</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>h</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> are measured in centimeters. Selected values of <math alttext="r of h" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>r</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>h</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> are given in the table shown. (a) Approximate <math alttext="r prime of 3.1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msup><mi>r</mi><mo>′</mo></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>3.1</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></math> using the average rate of change of <math alttext="r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> over the interval <math alttext="0 less than or equal to h, less than or equal to 6.2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>h</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>6.2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Show the computations that lead to your answer. Indicate units of measure.

(b) Interpret the meaning of <math alttext="the fraction 1 over 20, end fraction, times, the integral from 0 to 20, of, r of h, d h" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>20</mn></mfrac><msubsup><mo>∫</mo><mn>0</mn><mn>20</mn></msubsup><mi>r</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>h</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mi>h</mi></mstyle></math> in the context of the problem. Use a trapezoidal sum with the three subintervals <math alttext="open bracket, 0 comma 6.2, close bracket" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfenced close="]" open="["><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>6.2</mn></mrow></mfenced></math>, <math alttext="open bracket, 6.2 comma 13, close bracket" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfenced close="]" open="["><mrow><mn>6.2</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>13</mn></mrow></mfenced></math>, and <math alttext="open bracket, 13 comma 20, close bracket" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfenced close="]" open="["><mrow><mn>13</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>20</mn></mrow></mfenced></math> to approximate the value of <math alttext="the fraction 1 over 20, end fraction, times, the integral from 0 to 20, of, r of h, d h" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>20</mn></mfrac><msubsup><mo>∫</mo><mn>0</mn><mn>20</mn></msubsup><mi>r</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>h</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mi>h</mi></mstyle></math>.

(c) The radius of the circular cross section at height <math alttext="h" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> above the base of the bottle can also be modeled by the function <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="h" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>h</mi></math> and <math alttext="f of h" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>f</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mi>h</mi><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> are measured in centimeters. Let <math alttext="f of h equals, 3 times, the square root of, 2 minus, 1.25 times the cosine of, open parenthesis, the fraction pi over 100, end fraction, times, open parenthesis, h minus 20, close parenthesis, squared, close parenthesis, end root" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>h</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn><msqrt><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>1.25</mn><mi>cos</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mi>π</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>100</mn></mrow></mfrac><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mi>h</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>20</mn></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></msqrt></mrow></math> for <math alttext="0 less than or equal to h, less than or equal to 20" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>h</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>20</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Based on the model, at a height of <math alttext="h equals 12" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>h</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>12</mn></math> centimeters, is the radius increasing or decreasing as <math alttext="h" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>h</mi></math> increases? Give a reason for your answer.
(d) Using the model <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> defined in part (c), find the volume of the bottle.

topic.text: 2.1: Defining Average and Instantaneous Rates of Change at a Point

skill.text: Skill 1.E: Apply appropriate mathematical rules or procedures, with and without technology.
